questions.q: A proposition is a declarative sentence that is:
questions.explanation: By definition, a proposition must have a definite truth value (True or False) and cannot be ambiguous, a question, or a command.
options: Either true or false, but not both

questions.q: Which of the following is a proposition?
questions.explanation: A is a question, B is a command, and D is an open sentence (variable x). C is a declarative statement with a definitive truth value (True).

questions.q: Which of the following is NOT a proposition?
questions.explanation: Questions do not assert a fact that can be judged as true or false.
options: Cairo is the capital of Egypt

questions.q: The truth value of the proposition "5 - 2 = 1" is:
questions.explanation: 5 - 2 equals 3, not 1. Therefore, the statement is valid but False.

questions.q: The truth value of a proposition is denoted by:
questions.explanation: T and F are the standard symbols for True and False.

questions.q: The negation of the proposition "Michael's PC runs Linux" is:
questions.explanation: Negation simply denies the statement. 'Runs Windows' is too specific; he could run macOS.
options: It is not the case that Michael's PC runs Linux
Michael's PC runs Linux and Unix

questions.q: The negation of a proposition p is denoted by:
questions.explanation: The symbol ¬ represents the logical NOT operator.

questions.q: The negation (¬p) is true when:
questions.explanation: If a statement is False, its negation must be True.

questions.q: If p is True, then the truth value of ¬p is:
questions.explanation: Negation inverts the truth value.

questions.q: The conjunction (p ∧ q) is true when:
questions.explanation: Conjunction (AND) requires all operands to be true.
options: Both p and q are true
At least one of p or q is true
Both p and q are false
p is true and q is false

questions.q: The conjunction (p ∧ q) is true only when:
questions.explanation: Same as above; AND is only satisfied if both conditions are met.
options: Both p and q are true
p is true and q is false
p is false and q is true

questions.q: The disjunction (p ∨ q) is false only when:
questions.explanation: Disjunction (OR) is true if at least one input is true. It is false only if all inputs are false.
options: Both p and q are true
One is true and the other is false
Both p and q are false

questions.q: The disjunction (p ∨ q) is false only when:
questions.explanation: Repetition of the rule: False OR False = False.
options: Both p and q are false

questions.q: The exclusive or (p ⊕ q) is true when:
questions.explanation: XOR (Exclusive OR) checks for inequality. It is true if inputs are different (one True, one False).
options: Both p and q are true
Both p and q are false
Exactly one of p and q is true

questions.q: The exclusive or (p ⊕ q) is true when:
questions.explanation: XOR is distinct from inclusive OR because it evaluates to False if both inputs are True.
options: Exactly one of p or q is true

questions.q: In the conditional statement p → q, the proposition p is called the:
questions.explanation: The 'if' part of the statement is the hypothesis or antecedent.

questions.q: In the conditional statement p → q, the proposition q is called:
questions.explanation: The 'then' part of the statement is the conclusion or consequence.

questions.q: The statement p → q is false only in which case?
questions.explanation: An implication is broken (False) only when a true promise (hypothesis) leads to a false result (conclusion).
options: p is false and q is true
p is false and q is false
p is true and q is false

questions.q: The conditional statement p → q is false when:
questions.explanation: This is the unique definition of a false implication.
options: p is true and q is false

questions.q: A truth table for a compound statement with 3 variables will have how many rows?
questions.explanation: The number of rows is 2 raised to the power of the number of variables (2³ = 8).

questions.q: The converse of the statement p → q is:
questions.explanation: The converse swaps the hypothesis and the conclusion.

questions.q: The converse of p → q is:
questions.explanation: Same as above; q implies p.

questions.q: Which statement is logically equivalent to the conditional p → q?
questions.explanation: An implication and its contrapositive always share the same truth value.

questions.q: The contrapositive of p → q is:
questions.explanation: Contrapositive swaps and negates both sides.

questions.q: The contrapositive of p → q is:
questions.explanation: Contrapositive: If not q, then not p.

questions.q: Which statement is logically equivalent to p → q?
questions.explanation: This is a fundamental rule in logic; proofs often rely on proving the contrapositive instead of the direct statement.

questions.q: The inverse of p → q is:
questions.explanation: The inverse negates both sides but keeps the order: If not p, then not q.

questions.q: The inverse of p → q is:
questions.explanation: Same as above; negation without swapping.

questions.q: A biconditional statement p ↔ q is true when:
questions.explanation: Biconditional (if and only if) requires both sides to match (either both True or both False).
options: p and q have different truth values
p and q have the same truth values
p is true regardless of q

questions.q: The biconditional statement p ↔ q is true when:
questions.explanation: It represents equivalence; they must stand or fall together.
options: p is true and q is false
p and q have different truth values
p and q have the same truth values

questions.q: The statement p ↔ q is true when:
questions.explanation: Equivalent to (p → q) ∧ (q → p).
options: p and q have different truth values
p and q have the same truth values
p is true regardless of q
q is false regardless of p

questions.q: Which operator has the highest precedence?
questions.explanation: Negation applies to the immediate variable next to it before any other operations are performed.

questions.q: The highest precedence among logical operators belongs to:
questions.explanation: Standard order: ¬, then ∧, then ∨, then →, then ↔.

questions.q: Which operator has the lowest precedence among these?
questions.explanation: The biconditional (↔) is usually evaluated last.

questions.q: In computer bit operations, the bit '0' usually represents:
questions.explanation: 0 maps to False (OFF).

questions.q: In computer bit operations, the bit '1' represents:
questions.explanation: 1 maps to True (ON).

questions.q: In computer logic, a bit value of '0' represents:
questions.explanation: Standard binary logic convention.

questions.q: The length of the bit string "101010011" is:
questions.explanation: Count the digits: there are 9 bits.

questions.q: The bit string 101010011 has a length of:
questions.explanation: Count of bits = 9.

questions.q: What is the bitwise AND of strings 01 and 11?
questions.explanation: First bit: 0&1=0. Second bit: 1&1=1. Result: 01.

questions.q: What is the bitwise AND of 01 and 11?
questions.explanation: 0 AND 1 is 0. 1 AND 1 is 1. Result: 01.

questions.q: What is the bitwise OR of 10 and 01?
questions.explanation: 1 OR 0 is 1. 0 OR 1 is 1. Result: 11.

questions.q: The result of Bitwise XOR of bit strings (1010) and (1100) is:
Which logic gate produces the negation of a signal?
questions.explanation: An inverter (NOT gate) flips the bit.

questions.q: A logic gate that produces the negation (¬p) is called:
questions.explanation: Also known as a NOT gate.

questions.q: The gate that produces ¬p as output is the:
questions.explanation: Input 1 -> Output 0; Input 0 -> Output 1.

questions.q: In logic circuits, the component that gives output 1 only when input is 0 is:
questions.explanation: This describes the behavior of a NOT gate (Inverter).

questions.q: The output of an XOR gate is 1 when:
questions.explanation: XOR (Exclusive OR) outputs True (1) only when the inputs differ.
options: One input is 1 and the other is 0

questions.q: Logic gates are used to build:
questions.explanation: Logic gates are the physical building blocks of digital electronic circuits (like CPUs).

questions.q: The combinatorial circuit representing the expression (p ∧ ¬q) ∨ ¬r consists of:
questions.explanation: You need Inverters for ¬q and ¬r, an AND gate for the conjunction, and an OR gate for the disjunction.
options: Two Inverters, one AND gate, and one OR gate
